docs.lead_paragraph: Supreme Court Upholds State Law on Managed Care States can require managed health care plans to accept any qualified doctor who wants to be a participating provider, the Supreme Court ruled in a unanimous decision that resolved a legal dispute over state health care regulation. The court upheld a 1994 Kentucky law that prevents H.M.O.'s from limiting the pool of doctors or from retaliating against doctors who recommend too many treatments or complain about working conditions. About half the states have enacted similar laws, known as ''any willing provider'' laws. [Page A16.]
docs.snippet: Supreme Court Upholds State Law on Managed Care  States can require managed health care plans to accept any qualified doctor who wants to be a participating provider, the Supreme Court ruled in a unanimous decision that resolved a legal dispute over...

docs.lead_paragraph: Insurance industry officials said yesterday that they would not let a Supreme Court decision on health plans hobble managed care, but some industry experts said the ruling was part of trend that is shrinking the role of insurers. Rejecting an appeal by Aetna, Humana and other insurance companies, the court unanimously upheld a 1994 Kentucky law that opens membership in insurance networks to any doctor willing to accept an insurer's rules and payment rates.

headline.main: Industry Says Decision Won't Set Back Managed Care

docs.lead_paragraph: In a break with party leaders, centrist Democrats proposed today that Medicare provide drug benefits immediately to people who have low incomes or high prescription drug expenses. Members of both parties said Congress could eventually embrace such a plan if lawmakers could not agree on more ambitious proposals to pay drug costs for all Medicare beneficiaries, regardless of income.

headline.main: Medicare Drug Benefit Plan Is Proposed by 2 Democrats

docs.abstract: Centrist Democrats propose that Medicare provide drug benefits immediately to people with low incomes or high prescription drug expenses; Reps Cal Dooley and Rahm Emanuel offer plan as alternative to more ambitious proposals (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One obvious cause of the rise in Medicare costs (news article, March 26) is the increasing number of very elderly patients with many medical problems. But a far bigger cause is the unnecessary workups done by physicians so they don't miss any possibility, however remote, to protect themselves against bounty hunters and trial lawyers. A diagnosis is always subject to second-guessing by trial lawyers. They may get a windfall for a few clients, while the whole country suffers as medical costs soar.
docs.abstract: Dr Lalit K Gupta letter on Mar 26 article blames rising Medicare costs in part on unnecessary workups doctors must do to guard against remote possibilities to protect selves from suits

docs.lead_paragraph: The mysterious respiratory illness suspected of sickening 1,800 people around the world seemed to loom at the United States' gates yesterday as a jetliner from Asia was briefly quarantined in California, a Congressional subcommittee announced that it would investigate the illness and two more people died in Canada. In the United States, however, it seemed more an epidemic of nervousness than of illness, as it was in California when no one on the jet was found to have the disease. Thus far, the nation has had 69 reported cases of the disease, called SARS for severe acute respiratory syndrome, but no fatalities or near-fatalities.

headline.main: Worries Over Respiratory Illness Prompt Quarantine of Jet in California

docs.abstract: American Airlines flight from Tokyo is held on tarmac in San Jose, California, for two hours after several passengers complain of symptoms that could be severe acute respiratory syndrome; SARS is not diagnosed; US has had 59 reported cases but no fatalities; two more people die in Canada, both linked to outbreak at Toronto hospital, bringing death toll in Canada to six; State Department to allow nonessential US personnnel to leave posts in Hong Kong and Guangzhou, China, as business and other travel to region is curtailed sharply; photos; map; chronology of outbreak (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Medicare Recipients Face 12.4% Rise in Premiums'' (news article, March 26): The real story is not that Medicare beneficiaries may have to pay more, or that physicians may be paid less next year. It is that we are utterly unprepared to accept that America is growing older and sicker, and that we must make careful decisions about how we spend our limited resources.
docs.abstract: Dr Amnon Schlegel letter on Mar 26 article cites need to set priorities for Medicare spending as America grows older and sicker

docs.lead_paragraph: Express Scripts Inc., which manages prescription benefits for employers and insurers, received $2.48 billion in rebates and fees from pharmaceutical companies in the last three years. The company disclosed the rebates under a change in accounting practices in a regulatory filing, accounting for the money as a decrease to cost of goods sold, rather than an increase to revenue. The change means Express Scripts' revenue for 2000 through 2002 was reduced by the same amount, a company spokesman, Steven Littlejohn, said. Express Scripts said in the filing that it had received a second subpoena in a federal inquiry of pharmacy-benefit prices. Barrett Toan, the chief executive of Express Scripts, said last month that his company would disclose financial relationships with drug makers because of concern that the dealings might create conflicts of interest.

headline.main: EXPRESS SCRIPTS DISCLOSES $2.48 BILLION IN REBATES, FEES

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's deadline for winning $600 million in savings from city unions is expected to pass today without an agreement, union and city officials said yesterday, leaving another giant question mark hovering over the city's finances. With no firm answer from the city's unions, and roughly $1.7 billion in help requested from the state that may not materialize, the city could have a great deal of trouble balancing its budget in the fiscal year that begins three months from now, on July 1.

headline.main: Deadline on Cost-Cutting Steps Nears Without Unions' Reply

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's deadline for winning $600 million in savings from city unions is expected to pass without agreement, leaving city's budget in question and looming prospect of thousands of layoffs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If doctors followed all the government recommendations aimed at preventing disease and injury, they would spend more than seven hours a day on those standards and have almost no time left for actual treatment, researchers have calculated. Writing in The American Journal of Public Health this month, the researchers say the issue will become more important as more screening tests are developed.

headline.main: Doctors Try to Beat the Clock

docs.abstract: Duke University researcher Dr J Lloyd Michener and Dr Kimberly S H Yarnall publish report in American Journal of Public Health that shows doctors following government standards for preventive care would need to spend more than seven hours per day meeting those requirements, leaving little time to spend on actual treatment; suggests changes in administration of medical services; cartoon (S)
